Chapter 29: The Great Extinction
At that time, the Buddha was traveling with the great assembly to the twin trees forest;
The Brahma-like voice told Ananda to spread the bedding at the twin trees.
The Buddha then lay down on the rope bed, leaning on his right side;
Facing the west, with his head to the north and his feet stacked.
At that time, the virtuous Subhadra, who cultivated kindness and removed restlessness,
Wanted to see the Buddha and seek liberation, so he came and said to Ananda:
I know the teacher of gods and humans will reach the time of extinction;
Therefore, I come to see the one who is difficult to see and realizes all dharmas.
Now I seek to pay homage and see him, how does one reach the end of suffering?
If I cannot see him now, it will be like the sun setting into eternal darkness.
He asked Ä€nanda to pass through, but Ä€nanda's mind was troubled;
He then said to Subhadra:
Now is not the time to see the teacher.
The Buddha, with his omniscience, clearly saw the one who should be liberated;
With the appearance of a hundred merits, he looked at Subhadra with a compassionate mind.
The Buddha, with a gentle voice, said to Ä€nanda:
Do not go against the one who has come; I have appeared in the world to do good.
Subhadra obtained what he wished for and was filled with joy and excitement;
He immediately went to where the Buddha was, and his wish would surely be fulfilled.ğŸ”½At that time, the wise Subhadra,
Humble and respectful of the Buddha's virtues,
Bowed in reverence and politely said to the World-Honored One:
The former teachers who awakened to the world, I wonder from whom the Honored One attained the Way?
Having already attained liberation, he also liberates sentient beings.
I wish to be shown and enlightened, perhaps I may be able to awaken;
Therefore, I have come to respectfully pay homage to the Venerable One, not daring to claim my own wisdom and power.
The Buddha saw Subhadra coming and felt great joy and respect in his heart;
He spoke to him about the sages and showed him the cessation of suffering and non-action.
At that time, Subhadra heard this and immediately attained liberation;
His deluded and mistaken thoughts were awakened, and he attained the path of liberation.
He had originally held mistaken and inverted views, and therefore followed delusion and transmigration;
He had sixty-two inverted views, and because of this, he was submerged in the world.
All of them were completely eliminated, and the white-robed one attained the Way;
His defilements ended and he became an arhat, no longer subject to rebirth.
He realized the path the Buddha had taken and the love that arises from worldly conditions;
The thirst of love was extinguished on both sides, and the mind was freed from all the bonds of suffering.
He realized what the Buddha had taught, the profound and correct true teachings;
He eliminated the defilements of the mind and his heart was pure without any remaining impurities.
The birth and death of the world, Subhadra contemplates in truth;
He says the world is annihilated, this view is removed from the eyes.
The world originally returns to destruction, the mind awakens to this;
The world has the view of permanence, false doubts suddenly disappear.
What was previously grasped, he abandons these inverted views;
Hearing the Buddha's true good words, he opens his compassionate mind and accepts them.
Because of the good roots he cultivated in his past lives,
He wishes to enter the city of nirvana, thus he is quickly liberated.
Having attained the good and unconditioned, removing darkness and awakening to the truth,
He establishes the eternal nectar, eliminating all afflictions.
At that time, seeing the World-Honored Buddha, wishing to abandon and enter nirvana,
He looked at the Buddha with a compassionate mind, and this thought arose:
It is not appropriate for me now to see the Buddha abandon his life and practice;
The torch of the world, the refuge of sentient beings.ğŸ”½I will first give away my body,
Wishing to make offerings to all, until the Buddha, the Heaven of Heavens, gives up his life.
With immeasurable joy in his mind, he rose and touched his five limbs to the ground;
He bowed his head at the Buddha's feet, giving rise to a determined intention like a mountain.
In an instant, he quickly extinguished it, like a great cloud rising;
It rained down sweet moisture everywhere, extinguishing the wild fire.
The Buddha told the bhiká¹£us:
Make offerings to Subhadra's body.
The Buddha's last disciple, who delivered him and established the city of nirvÄá¹‡a.
Then he leaned on his right side, lying on a rope bed;
Wishing to give up the Buddha's body, he ended his life span.
When the first watch of the night was about to pass, the light of the stars and moon diminished;
The forest and beasts became silent.
The Buddha told the disciples:
You should respectfully uphold the precepts, like a revered teacher illuminating the world;
After I pass away, follow them without transgression.
Purify and restrain body, speech, and mind, abandon profit-seeking, and seek great peace;ğŸ”½Do not engage in farming, animal husbandry, or servitude, or hoard grain, treasures, or gardens.
Do not plant trees or cut them down;
Do not build walls or fences for your own sake.
Do not study astronomy or astrology, or concoct medicinal prescriptions;
Know the proper time for meals, cultivate yourself, and do not expect respect.
Do not conceal your own faults, or use spells to make a living;
Do not serve as a messenger for the king, or predict good or bad fortune.
In the future, you should have sufficient clothing, food, medicine, and tonics;
Always restrain your mind, be content, guard your limits, and endure hardships.
If you can diligently uphold these precepts,
The root of the precepts, the nirvana that carries the characteristics.
From this arises concentration and wisdom, the precepts are complete and harmonious;
Protecting and guarding can be fully accomplished, wisdom increases and benefits.
Eliminating all afflictions and troubles, this leads to nirvana;
These words are the seal of the precepts, because of recognizing and guarding the precepts.
If the precepts are complete and unbroken, fully accomplished without deficiency;
Then they are pure and good, liberated from afflictions and troubles, and extinguished.
Those who have no precepts, they have no Å›ramaá¹‡as;
Because of the precepts, they are established on the ground, and become excellent Å›ramaá¹‡as.
Having already established the complete pure precepts, the mind does not run to various desires;
Exerting oneself, one restrains and makes it abide, subduing it so that it does not arise.
Like turning a cow away from seedlings, if one indulges in thoughts of evil;
One deviates from the pure precepts, and falls into great decline.
If one encounters a fierce enemy, one suffers in this life;
Those who follow desires, in this world and the next,
Fully experience all kinds of suffering and harm, therefore one should not follow desires;
Those who are delighted by desires, later will surely encounter great suffering.
People should not fear being burned by a raging fire;
Do not fear poisonous snakes, nor fierce and evil thieves.
Those who harm and rob people of their lives, should fear their own deluded mind;
Like a fool seeing honey in a cliff, not caring about the danger of falling.
Like an elephant without a hook, jumping around like a monkey;
The mind follows desires day and night, do not allow it to follow its convenience.
Those who do not extinguish their minds, their bodies cannot rest;
Those who are able to tame their minds, do not deviate from nirvana.
Obtaining food is like taking medicine, one should not give rise to love or hatred;
The food obtained through skillful means, just enough to cure hunger and sustain the body.
It is like a swarm of bees collecting the essence of flowers;
The timely offering of food, without destroying people's kindness and respect.
Do not trouble the generous, do not frequently employ good animals;
The generous become weary if troubled, good animals become exhausted if frequently employed.
You should diligently apply skillful means day and night,
Do not indulge in sleep, wasting the life that is difficult to obtain.
The world is burned by death, who can sleep peacefully at night?
Surrounded by enemies and thieves, how can one be at ease in fear?
You should abandon the long-lasting defilements and impurities,
Defilements and impurities cover peaceful sleep, awakening and eliminating defilements and impurities.
Shame and conscience are the clothes and ornaments, the hook for the elephant;
Those who abandon shame and conscience are abandoned by the multitude of virtues and goodness.
Those who uphold a sense of shame and dishonor are called humans;
Those who have a stern countenance but do not know shame are called animals.
Even if you are cut limb from limb, your mind should not become disturbed;
Do not violate the prohibitions, and do not speak harsh words with your mouth.
Precepts are precisely patience, and they are also a powerful force;
If you cannot endure others' harsh words, you will never attain liberation.
Anger destroys the Dharma and loses one's reputation, and good thoughts delight the enemy;
The mind is poisonous, do not listen to it, and let it stay for a short while.
Among all the strong enemies of goodness, none surpasses anger;
It is swift and without comparison, destroying kindness and precepts.
Those who live at home have attachments, so even if they are angry, the offense is not serious;
But if one who upholds the precepts is angry, the offense is serious, like cold water producing fire.
Shaving the head, wearing the Dharma robes, holding a bowl to beg for food;
One should not associate with anger, as it is not suitable for one who upholds the world's conduct.
When arrogance increases, goodness is diminished, this is so even for householders;
How much more so for one who has left home and renounced attachments, and tames the mind in concentration?
The true Dharma is upright and correct, not mixed with falsehood;
The true Dharma establishes good deeds, while falsehood is deceptive.
The sages worry about accumulating wealth, while those with few desires are free from suffering;
Therefore, my disciples, by having few desires, increase good qualities.
You should know contentment, and then the mind will be stable;

Contentment is happiness in the human realm, while lack of contentment leads to suffering in the heavenly realm.ğŸ”½The wealthy are not content, while the poor are greedy for wealth; knowing contentment is true wealth.
The discontented poor wander about, while the contented are pitied by others.
Those who seek liberation should not rely on the confusion of the crowd;
Even the Heavenly Emperor and those below him respect those who are alone and tranquil.
You should eliminate affection and love, as affection and love are the abode of suffering;
Abandon the family and affection and love, like an old elephant sinking in mud.
For those with a courageous and progressive mind, there are no difficulties in any matter;
The nature of water is penetratingly soft and weak, but it can gradually wear through stone.
If one drills for fire and rests frequently, one cannot obtain fire;
If one diligently drills and seeks fire, the diligent one will succeed.
Therefore, one should establish diligence and head towards the gate of nirvana;
Evil goes against the path of non-action, you should be careful not to do it.
If one guards one's will without error or confusion, the various evils cannot descend;
Guarding one's will is the friend of the ascetic, losing one's will forgets all goodness.
If one's will is armored and prepared, the enemy cannot defeat it;
If one's mind is focused and wears the armor of virtue, the afflictions cannot conquer it.
For those who are focused and concentrated, they clearly understand the birth and death of the world;
Therefore, one should concentrate the mind, and when the mind is concentrated, suffering does not arise.
If one wishes to cross a flowing stream, one relies on bridges, rafts, and floating logs;
If one wishes to cross all suffering, concentration is the foremost boat.
You wise ones who are detached, now manifest the worldly Dharma;
If there is this, then one attains liberation, but those outside the Dharma are not loved.
It is not said that abandoning the household is like armor, good medicine, sharp weapons;
Boats and ships cross flowing rivers, wisdom crosses birth and death.
Therefore, always listen to the Dharma, and follow the teachings of the Dharma;
The wise see correctly, the unwise are blind and deluded.
The mind together with afflictions, will never attain liberation;
If one truly wishes to seek liberation, diligently remove the afflictions.
The Å›ramaá¹‡a studies to regulate the mind, removing thoughts of negligence;
The mind of the Heavenly Emperor is joyful, the asuras have no joy.
I teach you all that is good, you should diligently cultivate;
Extensively set up various skillful means, and lead to nirvana.
In the quiet and secluded mountains, forests, and empty abodes;
Study concentration there, do not regret after I am gone.
A good doctor exhausts various methods, and compounds many medicines;
The sick take them and are cured, the doctor does not take them himself.
The guide leads correctly, those who follow have no worries;
Those who go against it are harmed, because they do not heed the danger.
I have already expounded the Four Noble Truths for you all;
Those with doubts should ask, now is the right time.
When the Buddha commanded this, the disciples were silent and said nothing;
Aniruddha knew their thoughts and said in the great assembly:
The sun can be made cool, the moon can be made hot;
These four truths are truly correct, and cannot be violated in the end.
The truth of suffering is oppressed by suffering, and in the end, love has suffering;
It is said by all Buddhas that the truth of cessation ends love and ends.
The nectar of the eightfold right path, quiescence is nirvana;
Awakening to this is the assembly of Å›ramaá¹‡as, the Buddha's later disciples who cross over suffering.
The assembly who have not yet crossed over, first entering the path, old and young;
The Buddha roughly speaks of arhats, like a flash of lightning illuminating the path.
Those who have already attained liberation, crossing over birth and death;
The assembly all harbor grief, the teacher's extinction is too swift.
The Buddha heard Ä€nanda's words, like this correct and true speech;
Desiring to strengthen the assembly's resolve, he compassionately spoke these words:
Even if one had a kalpa's lifespan, it would surely end in the end;
I have fully practiced goodness, what use is a long life?
Those in the world and in the heavens whom I should deliver,
Half have been delivered and half shown the path, the Dharma has been transmitted and can abide.
You should be aware and restrained, do not think of me too much;
Just diligently speak the expedient means, do not encounter the pain of separation.
Using the lamp of wisdom to dispel darkness, realizing the world has no solidity;
At the end of life, the mind is filled with joy, like a serious illness being cured.
The wise one is free from misfortune, far away from evil people;
Having abandoned these two afflictions, why would one have worries?
You should diligently cultivate goodness, all will die in turn;
I will enter the city of nirvana, the time has now arrived.
Thus I will abandon the practice of life, this is my final word.
The Buddha then contemplated the first meditation of detachment from desire,
Rising from the first meditation, he contemplated the second meditation,
Thus, he went through the four dhyÄnas;
Thus, he went through the nine dhyÄnas, back and forth, in order,
The World-Honored One, the Heaven of Heavens, returned to the first dhyÄna.
Rising from the first dhyÄna, he pondered again and reached the fourth dhyÄna;
The Buddha then carefully contemplated, going through the dhyÄnas in order and reverse.
He then rose from there again, slightly shaking his mind;
Then, he abandoned the practice of life and entered the city of nirvÄá¹‡a.
As soon as the Buddha abandoned the practice of life, the earth shook in six ways;
In the sky, there was a great torch, like the burning fire at the end of the eon.
There was a great fire in the four directions, like the asuras;
Burning the heavenly forests and marshes, called the joy of extinguishing desire.
A violent rain of hail and dust, lightning flashing like flames;
The entire world was like a great fire, with thunderclaps extremely frightening.
Uprooting trees and toppling mountain cliffs;
Like the wind at the end of the eon, Causing immeasurable destruction.
The bright sun loses its luster, The stars and moon are dim and unclear;
The sun and moon both lose their light, As if smeared with mud.
Although the sun and moon shine together, They are murky and not clear;
Unable to discern east and west, Day and night cannot be known.
The World-Honored One is shrouded in darkness, Rivers all flow in reverse;
Beside the Buddha tree, in the twin forest, Sorrowful flowers fall.
The water in the rivers is all hot, Like boiling hot water in a cauldron;
The twin trees wither, Bending over the World-Honored One's body.
The five-headed great dragon king, Grieved and pained, his body slackens;
Either dazed and hot, gazing at the Buddha, Weeping, his eyes all red.
Immediately he emits hot breath, The stench is indescribable;
Burning and scorching the throat, like vomiting with a heavy heart illness.
Contemplating the world is impermanent, admonishing oneself to forcefully remove worries;
The king of one's own mind leads the way, thinking of the Dharma to restrain crying.
The devas of the Pure Abode, understanding the path, their minds are disciplined and settled;
Silent and not crying, they pity the world and may arise or cease.
The foremost yaká¹£a god, the powerful dragon king god;
The devas who cherish the Dharma, their grief fills the void.
Universally covered in worry, wandering about, their sorrow moves;
The great sounds of various kinds, fill the world.
The demons have attained their wish, and the evil soldiers rejoice;ğŸ”½Dancing and thundering, they release various great sounds.
They shout loudly and transmit the order, saying:
Our lord's strong enemy is gone, from now on who else will be able to cross his boundaries?
The Buddha's virtues collapsed and fell, like a great elephant's tusk breaking;
Like a mountain peak crumbling, like a great bull's horn being pulled out.
The Buddha now abandons his body and life, the devas and humans of the world;
No longer have anything to rely on, losing support in this way.
Like the sky without the sun, like a country losing its granary;
Like a flower pond covered in frost, the flowers are all withered and damaged.
The World-Honored One abandons his body and life, peacefully hidden in nirvana;
All beings with form, none do not lose their essence and splendor.
Chapter 30: Lamenting the Unconditioned, Buddha's Life Sutra, Lamenting the Unconditioned At that time, from the sky, the heavenly jeweled palace shone brightly;
Drawn by a thousand elephants and a chariot, suspended in the sky above;
Respectfully gazing at the Buddha, lying down and abandoning his life;
Feeling moved and lamenting, he spoke these words:
Dwelling in the great cycle of birth and death, all is impermanent;
Just born, prosperity arises, suddenly declining, it perishes.
Revolving towards what is pleasant, various sufferings arise;
Completely extinguishing all suffering, the unconditioned is supremely blissful.
The firewood of various kinds of birth and death, burn it until nothing remains;
The smoke of the virtue and praise of wisdom pervades the heavens and the world.
The water of impermanence suddenly arrives, extinguishing the Buddha's great light;
Like a wild fierce fire suddenly encountering a great rainstorm.
There were also celestial sages, with agile and wholesome minds, well-tamed;
Dwelling in the palace of the Pure Abodes, pure and free from desires.
Seeing the Buddha, they greatly loved and respected him, weeping like rain from the clouds;
Their minds were heavy like Mount Sumeru, and they spoke these words:
In the world, there will never be one who is born and yet does not die;
From ancient times until now, no one has been born and lived long.
The upper, middle, and lower [realms] are thoroughly understood, and there is nothing that is not known with certainty;
Even this is not yet free from [death], and the rest are difficult to live long.
This is the great guide in the world, removing evil and showing the right path;
The eye of wisdom is the foremost, observing the world turning upside down.
Thus, when the wisdom of the world perishes, it will return to the guidance of evil,
Just like the blind without eyes, losing their way on the level road.
The disciple with the best heavenly eye was named Ä€nanda;
His feelings of love and hatred were exhausted, and the toil of birth and death was ended.
Seeing that the Buddha had already attained nirvana, the world would be in darkness;
With his faculties tranquil and his mind extinguished, he then sighed and said these words:
Dwelling in the great birth and death, the meaning of wisdom is not yet fully understood;
The world is like a mist, disappearing in an instant.
The impermanence vajra hammer strikes the Buddha's jeweled Mount Sumeru;
Suddenly it collapses and crumbles, now falling to the ground.
What is born in the world is so fragile, not one thing can be relied upon;
It is fleeting and not solid, agitated and moving, coming together and then dispersing.
The law of the destruction of the entire world is like a dream, without a self;
The Buddha, the lion, can subdue the dust and afflictions, the elephant falls by itself.
Those who have not yet attained the path, how can they not fear this?
Contemplating the world as unreliable, like morning dew and bubbles.
The Buddha is called the teacher of gods and humans, the great vajra pillar;
Suddenly it collapses on the ground, where is its power now?
Six kinds of birth, five branches, one sprout, five fruit kernels;
All watered by the three trees, it is difficult to cut down with a laboring mind.
The Buddha, the elephant of great power, suddenly breaks the dust and affliction tree;
Crushing them to nothing left, they then fall to the ground themselves.
The thousand-eyed VajrapÄá¹‡i, and Indra receiving timely rain;
Establishing it in the true Dharma, extinguishing its suffering and cooling it.
Virtuous renown spreads far and wide, universally covering the world;
The teacher of all sages and worthies, peacefully and silently disappearing.
Renown and virtue are all-pervasive, the subtle Dharma is moistening;
Just like the rain in autumn, the Dharma waters fill the rivers and streams.
The celestial teacher extends his rescue and protection, King Self-Intent and his retinue;
Granting them the unconditioned path, his hidden body like the setting sun.
Rousing clouds and bringing down this rain, in autumn and winter it rains snow and frost;
The blazing flames of the raging fire, none can extinguish it.
Like the fire extinguished after the sacrifice is completed, now the fire of the celestial teacher;
Suddenly extinguished, silent and without light, the world will forever be in darkness.
The hope for liberation is cut off, and the original vow is lost;
Good reputation and virtue spread, pervading the ten directions.
Embracing the great compassion of the four immeasurables, pitying the multitude like one's own children;
None do not receive its goodness, how can it be that you have silently passed away?
Attaining the wonderful unattached path, the source of all buddhas;
The unobstructed wholesome dharmas, silently self-realized.
Using the supernormal power of lightness, realizing the body is the cessation of suffering;
For this reason, quickly abandoning the body, peacefully without conditioning.ğŸ”½Removing all mental obscurity, like the sun's thousand lights;
Extinguishing the defilements of sexual desire in the mind, like rain covering the dust on the ground.
No longer encountering the multitude of sufferings, not being oppressed by afflictions;
Already crossing the vast, boundless, bottomless ocean abyss.
Emerging and manifesting in the world, destroying the sufferings and poisonous afflictions;
Having compassion for the world, wishing to seek quiescence.
The multitude of good characteristics are extremely bright and radiant, quiescent like the Brahma Heaven King;
Great wisdom is universally complete, being the teacher of the world and the gods.
Transforming beings with goodness, refining afflictions and leaving behind evil;
Day and night increasing all goodness, like the moon at its initial appearance.
Always nurturing the multitude of goodness, virtues and praise are vast and universal;
Already understanding while at home, how much more so after leaving the household life.
In the past, making a vow for oneself, to engage in the battle with afflictions;
Having compassion for the poor and lowly, vowing to fulfill their wishes.
The Buddha, with a mind of equality, does not reject evil food;
Also, having no attachment, to fine and delicious flavors.
Generously giving what is difficult to let go, that which people are unable to do;
Not accepting from others, and not seeking benefit.
With major marks and great fame, naturally responding like an echo;
Extensively gathering wholesome intentions, decisively listening to the good.
Therefore manifesting a beautiful appearance, those who see it have the three defilements extinguished;
Speaking words that accomplish the Dharma and Vinaya, increasing the goodness of sentient beings.
Using the brightness of the marks of forbearance, making enemies with afflictions;ğŸ”½Accumulating immeasurable merit and virtue, not escaping impermanence.
The merit and virtue accumulated in the life to come, receiving retribution without limit;
Definitively attaining the right path, like firewood exhausted and fire extinguished.
Demonstrating the good path to sentient beings, cutting down the forest of afflictions;
Controlling all those who are bound by the attachments of birth and death.
Abandoning the eight superior and five destinies, seeing the three destinies;
Cutting down the three and exhausting the three, thereby attaining the three pure eyes.
Concealing one, awakening to one, attaining one, reaching the seven weighty ones;
Scattered without remainder, then vowed to be unobstructed.ğŸ”½Using nectar to fill the world, words cut off anger;
Using goodness to dye sentient beings, those in the world who are difficult to awaken.
Every time planting various roots of goodness, not giving evil to evil;
Establishing the banner of the true Dharma, in all worlds.
Turning the Dharma wheel in the Deer Park, universally delighting the world;
Accomplishing various liberations, purifying those who love themselves.
Seeing what has never been seen before, universally uniting with purity;
Awakening to the difficult things to awaken to, the phenomena that have never been awakened to.
Announcing to the world that it is impermanent, what is born will inevitably have suffering;
Announcing to the world that it is without self, without that long delusion.
Establishing the banner of the Dharma, destroying the high mountain of arrogance;
Just like a pillar of the seven treasures, collapsing in the sacrificial arena.
Do not harbor resentment towards those who slander you, and do not rejoice in praise;
Disgusted with birth, accept heavenly blessings, and skillfully seek non-birth.
Liberate yourself from the ocean of birth and death, and also liberate all others;
Enlighten yourself with wisdom, and also awaken sentient beings.
Like a nourishing cloud when it rains, like flowers in the mountains and forests;
Liberation is seen like the rising sun, and the correct view is bestowed upon others.
Although born in the world, not attached to worldly affairs;
Traveling the perilous path of the world, not following the same course.
The mind has never committed wrongdoing, and even attaining the good path is extinguished;
The entire world encounters difficulties and hardships, without any support or protection, it is lamentable.
Ignorance obscures their eyes, and they never consider anything;
Not thinking of devising skillful means, they seek the essentials for escaping from birth and death.
The sufferings of birth, old age, sickness, and death, afflict the world without exception;
Only the Buddha can save from suffering, bestowing the nectar.
In the past, the heavenly demon's troops could not conquer the Heavenly Teacher;
The power of impermanence is natural, and impermanence suddenly conquers it.
The World-Honored One's ears can hear the sounds of the trichiliocosm;
With spiritual powers, he ascends and descends, reaching the Brahma Heaven.
He knows the thoughts of sentient beings, down to the AvÄ«ci Hell;
The arising and ceasing of all birth and death, he sees and understands them all.
The Heavenly Teacher, from the beginning of birth, cycles through the changes;
He recollects as if seeing a face, exhausting the source of birth and death and defilements.
Endowed with the six supernormal knowledges and wisdom, fully awakened and certain;
Now, he abandons and discards, letting go of the remaining life and body.
In the world, love flows through birth and death, who can speak the Dharma to bring it to rest?
The world is foolish and ignorant, who will awaken and extinguish it with wisdom?
It is like a chariot without a driver, or a ship on the ocean without a captain;
Or like a serious illness without a good doctor - how can one sustain oneself?
It is like words separated from sincerity, seeking wisdom without the intention of awakening;
It is like a king losing his adornments, practicing goodness without patience.
Having already separated from these four things, their merits do not manifest;
Now that the Buddha has abandoned the world, it is difficult to accomplish difficult tasks without rescue.
It is like the fifth and sixth months of summer, pure without wind or clouds;
The intense heat burns intensely, and then it reaches all the insects and creatures.
The beings who should be liberated will now encounter difficulties everywhere;
The World-Honored One abandoning his life, how painful it is!
At that time, the heavens, with compassionate minds, pitifully spoke these words;
Because desire, anger, and delusion are thin, they praise the teacher and revile birth and death.
The disciples who have not yet been liberated, sadly wailing and crying;
Those who had already attained liberation contemplated the rise and fall of the Dharma.

Seeing the Buddha's lusterless form, having entered quiescent extinction, they could not awaken;
They wailed in unison, rolling like fish out of water.
Seeing the Buddha lying there, his limbs all stretched out,
It was like the passing of a wheel-turning king, with all the countries wailing.

The men, women, young, and old, were filled with grief and madness.ğŸ”½Some tore at their clothes, their pain causing them to bite their mouths;

Beating their chests, wailing to the heavens, lamenting the Buddha's immeasurable virtues.
Alas!
The teacher of gods and humans, the one relied upon by sentient beings;
Abandoning us so quickly, forever cut off, with no hope of reunion.
The great assembly wept in grief, each enduring as best they could;
The king of the powerful ones, in excruciating pain, lamented and said:
The teacher who awakens to the Dharma and enlightens the world, now lying down, never to rise again;
Like a great army disbanded, with the great banner no longer visible.
What was to be done has been done, the enlightened Buddha has already awakened;
In the world, like an eye, now suddenly in long slumber.
